content: The "Netizens Protection Act of 2001" prohibits the initiation of unsolicited electronic mail transmissions. The "Netizens Protection Act of 2001" prohibits unsolicited electronic mail transmissions that lack sender identification and opt-out options, and contain false or misleading information in the subject line. State laws regarding unsolicited commercial emails are not preempted. Individuals affected by violations of the Act can bring civil actions within one year of discovery, seeking injunctions to prevent further violations. The "Netizens Protection Act of 2001" allows individuals to bring civil actions for violations such as unsolicited emails without sender identification or opt-out options. Damages for each violation may not exceed $500, with the court able to treble the amount for subsequent violations. The court can also award full costs and attorneys' fees to the prevailing party. Damages awarded for a violation under subsection (a) are in addition to any other damages awardable under any other provision of law. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS AGAINST USE OF INTERACTIVE COMPUTER SERVICES TO INITIATE UNSOLICITED ELECTRONIC MAIL. Each interactive computer service provider must provide customers with a clear policy on unsolicited electronic mail, allowing customers to opt in or out of receiving such mail. Customers are prohibited from sending bulk unsolicited emails if the provider's policy prohibits it. The policy of the interactive computer service provider prohibits bulk transmissions of unsolicited emails. The provider can take legal action against violators, seeking injunctions, damages, and other appropriate relief. The court may award damages up to $500 for each unsolicited email sent in violation of the law. These damages are in addition to any other penalties that may apply. The court can also award costs, attorney fees, and expert witness fees to the prevailing party in a civil action. Venue for civil actions under this subsection can be in the district where the defendant or interactive computer service provider is located, does business, or where venue is proper under section 1391 of title 28, United States Code. Process can be served in any district where the defendant is located or can be found. SEC. 4. Protection of interactive computer service providers who take action to prevent unsolicited emails. They are not liable for harm resulting from failure to prevent such emails. This does not restrict liability for other services. SEC. 5. Definitions. For the purposes of this Act, the definitions of "bulk," "initiate the transmission," and "interactive computer service" are provided. Bulk refers to the transmission of identical or similar electronic mail messages to 50 or more recipients within a 7-day period. Initiating the transmission means originating the message, excluding actions of interactive computer services that only relay or handle messages. Interactive computer service is defined as per section 230(e) of the Communications Act of 1934. The term "unsolicited electronic mail" refers to electronic mail sent without prior permission or to individuals with whom the sender has no established relationship. Effective Date: This Act will be in effect 60 days after enactment and will apply to electronic mail transmissions initiated after that period.
